entry.title: Creating one single FIORI app with two or more FIORI apps or ODATA V4 Servcies as its tabs?
entry.content:
Hi,

I have developed few custom RAP OData V4 applications as list reports with CRUD operations, and I have also deployed them as Fiori apps. Now, I have a user requirement to consolidate a few of these apps into a single application, where each list report should be displayed as a separate tab within this new app.

I have searched blogs related to Fiori elements and the Fiori Elements FPM documentation, but I am unable to determine whether my requirement can be achieved using FPM. If it is possible, could you please suggest how to implement this? If not, is there an alternative way to achieve this using SAP UI5 freestyle application development to integrate the Fiori apps or OData services?

I would appreciate your guidance on the best approach to achieve this. 

Thank you!

entry.title: Why you should migrate FSVs to the Manage Global Hierarchies app
entry.content:
• What are Financial Statement Versions (FSVs)?
  • The traditional way: Manage Financial Statement Versions classic app (OB58)
  • The new way: Manage Global Hierarchies Fiori app
  • Why migrate to Manage Global Hierarchies?
  • Final Thoughts

In an earlier release of SAP S4/HANA Cloud Public Edition, a new app Manage Global Hierarchies was introduced as an enhanced solution for maintaining financial statement versions (FSVs). The app is set to replace the legacy Manage Financial Statement Versions classic app (ID: OB58). Migrating your FSV hierarchies to Manage Global Hierarchies is strongly recommended to leverage new capabilities, ensure continuity, and future-proof your processes.

In this blog, we‚Äôll explore the benefits of this new app, compare it with the classic app, and guide you through the migration process.

 

What are Financial Statement Versions (FSVs)?

A Financial Statement Version (FSV) is a hierarchical arrangement of G/L accounts. It is essential for: 

  • Generating financial statements
  • Creating various reports that are structured lists of account balances, such as trail balance
  • Planning in General Ledger Accounting, for example, by using balance sheet/income statement.

You can define different FSVs for various needs, for example:

  • For different organizational units, such as corporate group or company code.
  • For different levels of detail of your financial statements. For your accounting department, for example, you want to list the individual accounts with their respective balances. For senior management, you might want to summarize this information to create one set of financial statements for the whole group.

For more information, refer to Financial Statement Version (FSV) on the SAP Help Portal.

 

The traditional way: Manage Financial Statement Versions classic app (OB58)

For years, FSVs were maintained in the classic app OB58. To create, edit and display FSVs using this classic app, different business roles with differed business catalogs are required. For detailed information, see Define Financial Statement Versions (Classic App).

The following graphic provides an overview of the app user interface:

 

The new way: Manage Global Hierarchies Fiori app

The Manage Global Hierarchies Fiori app (ID: F2918) introduced in a recent release, modernizes FSV maintenance, and includes additional features that streamline the process. Aside from viewing, creating, and editing FSV hierarchies as in the classic app, the new app enables you to quickly create hierarchies by importing or copying from existing hierarchies in the event of structure changes or changing reporting needs. Additionally, you can check change logs and maintain node texts in multiple languages for applicable hierarchy types.

The following is an at-a-glance comparison:

Manage Global Hierarchies app

Manage Financial Statement Versions app (OB58)

  • Preferred for all countries/regions except for the Generate Annual Financial Statement - Austria app.
  • Fiori UI
  • For an FSV, you can assign G/L accounts from one chart of accounts.
  • Supports time-dependency, import/edit/export using a spreadsheet, reclassification attributes, and bank account grouping.
  • To use the sample FSVs delivered by SAP, you need to import them by choosing Import Hierarchy in the app.
  • Required for the Generate Annual Financial Statement - Austria app.
  • Classic UI
  • For an FSV, you can add G/L accounts from various charts of accounts.
  • Sample FSVs are delivered.

The following graphic provides an overview of the app user interface:

 

Why migrate to Manage Global Hierarchies?

We strongly recommend using the new Manage Global Hierarchies app to maintain FSVs. Rest assured, existing FSVs created in the classic app can be seamlessly migrated to the global hierarchies framework. We encourage you to do the migration as soon as possible for the following reasons:

  • The new app provides more robust functionality and greater flexibility to meet your business needs that are unavailable in the classic app.
  • The classic app is planned to be deprecated in the future.
  • New features are only delivered to the new app.

Given that, if you now access the classic app, you'll encounter a reminder directing you to use Manage Global Hierarchies for FSV maintenance.

 

Step-by-Step: Migrating FSVs to Manage Global Hierarchies

Migrating your existing FSV hierarchies is simple and efficient. Follow the steps below using the Migrate Financial Statement Versions to Global Hierarchies configuration activity. For more information, see How to Migrate FSVs to Global Hierarchies.

1. Open the configuration activity, select the line FSVN.

2. Select the old hierarchy of the FSVs you‚Äôd like to migrate, and choose the Migrate button. Take NC06 as an example.

3. In the migration details page, choose Migrate. 

4. You will then be navigated to the page below, which confirms that the hierarchy has been migrated to the Manage Global Hierarchies app.

5. To confirm the migration, open the Manage Global Hierarchies app and check the details of NC06.

6. Repeat the steps above to migrate all FSVs.

After completing the migration, click the Mark as Completed button in the aforementioned migration configuration activity to finalize the process and confirm that the FSV hierarchy type has been successfully and fully migrated.

Once the migration is complete and the hierarchy type has been marked as completed, the following applies:

  • The migrated FSVs are available in the Manage Global Hierarchies app. Their hierarchy structures, activation status (Draft or Active), and other settings, such as Allow Functional Areas, are kept.
  • Validity period is automatically set to 01.01.1900 - 31.12.9999 for the migrated FSVs.
  • The FSVs can only be edited in the Manage Global Hierarchies app. Changes made in this app are visible in all applications except for Define Financial Statement Versions and Manage Chart of Accounts.

 

Synchronize changes from the Development to the Production system

Newly created G/L accounts and FSVs or changes to G/L account master data are normally transported from your development system to the production system with the currently open business change project (BCP). However, if a new or changed object is urgently needed in your production system and you cannot wait for that BCP to be released and transported, the Synchronize G/L Account Master Data app helps you to copy these changes into your production system earlier. You can check Synchronize G/L Account Master Data (Two-System Landscape) for detailed information.

You can also refer to this video to learn how to use this app to sync the changes.

 

Final Thoughts

The Manage Global Hierarchies app clearly outperforms the classic Manage Financial Statement Versions app (OB58) in terms of features, efficiency, and adaptability. Migrating your FSV hierarchies to the new app ensures you are prepared for long-term updates, while enjoying new capabilities designed to meet evolving business needs.

We hope this blog helps you better understand the transition process. If you have questions or need further assistance, feel free to leave a comment below!

entry.title: Building a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views ‚Äì Part 3: Description for Hierarchy
entry.content:
Table of Contents:

  • Overview on this Blog
  • Approach
  • Technical Details & Source Code
  • Handling SACAccountType for hierarchy nodes
  • Loading hierarchy node descriptions in SAC
  • Conclusion

Overview on this Blog

Hi SAP Community,
This is part three of a three part blog series on How to Build a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views.

  • Part1 - Loading the ID & DESC of the GL
  • Part2 - Loading the hierarchy
  • Part3 - Loading the Desc for the Hierarchy nodes üëà

In Part 1, we focused on loading the GL Account ID and Description into an SAC public dimension by selectively filtering GLs from the Financial Statement Version (FSV).
In Part 2, we built the GL hierarchy structure, covering both leaf-level GLs and header nodes using CDS views.

In this final part, we will complete the hierarchy setup by loading the descriptions for hierarchy header nodes, so that the hierarchy in SAC is not only functional but also readable and user-friendly. Without descriptions , the Header nodes appear with technical IDs and the hierarchy becomes difficult to understand for business user. 

 

Approach

The idea here is simple, the hierarchy structure is already available in ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC. The hierarchy node texts are stored in HRRP_NODET. We join both using the hierarchy node ID. This approach ensures the texts are dynamically picked up from the source system and any changes to node descriptions are reflected automatically in SAC.

 

Technical Details & Source Code

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_HIERTXT'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Text for Hierarchy nodes'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_TXT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC as a left join hrrp_nodet as b on
a.Parent = b.hrynode {
    key a.Parent,
    b.nodetxt,
    a.MasterParent,
    case when a.Parent='0FSV1' then '' else a.SACAccountType end as SACAccountType
}
where b.hryid='FSV1' and b.spras='E' -- Choose your FSV and Language key as English

Handling SACAccountType for hierarchy nodes

In many systems, SACAccountType is not maintained at hierarchy node level. In such cases, we can derive or retain the account type based on the master hierarchy branch. This is important because:

  • SAC relies on SACAccountType to understand sign behavior.
  • Expense and Liability nodes need to subtract during aggregation.
  • Income and Asset nodes need to add.

By passing or deriving the account type consistently, we ensure correct aggregation behavior across all hierarchy levels.

P.S: In scenarios where hierarchy nodes involve multiple account types, inverse formulas can be provided to help SAC handle aggregation events correctly.

Loading hierarchy node descriptions in SAC

Hierarchy texts are loaded as a separate query in the SAC public dimension using our ZCDS_GLHIER_TXT CDS view. Only hierarchy node descriptions are updated whereas the existing hierarchy structure remains unchanged. Once this step is completed both GL accounts and hierarchy nodes display meaningful texts. The GL Account Public dimension will be fully ready and can be used in the planning model. This when consumed in the Input sheets becomes easier to understand for users.

The sample result would be like this. 

ID

Description

Hierarchy

Account type

40010000

Revenue - Good (Export)

FSV1_019

INC

40010001

Revenue - Good (Service)

FSV1_019

INC

FSV1_08

Turnover

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_09

Cost of Sales

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_011

Other Income

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_017

Taxation

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_018

Local Sales

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_019

Export Sales

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_020

Lease Income

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_0FSV1

Financial statement

FSV1_

 

FSV1_

 

<root>

 

With this final step:

  1. GL Account IDs and descriptions are loaded
  2. Hierarchy structure (leaf and header nodes) is built
  3. Hierarchy node descriptions are applied

This completes our end-to-end setup of a future-proof GL Account public dimension for SAC Planning using CDS views.

 

Conclusion

In this three-part series, we covered how to build a clean and scalable GL Account hierarchy for SAC Planning by selectively extracting FSV branches, constructing the hierarchy using CDS views, and finally enriching it with hierarchy node descriptions. This approach helps keep the SAC model & Input sheet clean, planning-friendly, and adaptable to future changes in the source system.

I hope this blog was helpful and proves useful for your upcoming planning implementations. If you found it helpful, feel free to hit a like, follow my profile, and drop a comment below. I‚Äôd love to hear your feedback.

entry.title: issue with duplicate Business Partner / Supplier / Customer creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are facing an issue with duplicate Business Partner / Supplier / Customer creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

System Details

  • Solution: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (2SL)

  • Apps Used:

    • Maintain Business Partner

    • Manage Supplier Master Data

    • Manage Customer Master Data

  • Country: India

Issue Description

While creating Business Partner / Supplier / Customer master data, the system is not checking for duplicate records, even when key attributes like GSTIN, Name, and Address are identical.

This results in:

  • Multiple suppliers/customers created with the same GSTIN

  • Manual duplicate cleanup and audit concerns

Expected Behavior

When creating a BP/Supplier/Customer:

  • System should detect duplicates based on GSTIN (Exact Match), Name, and Address.

  • Display warning or error depending on configuration

  • Prevent creation of suppliers/customers with same GSTIN

What We Have Checked

  • Using standard Fiori apps (not Migration Cockpit)

  • GSTIN is maintained in BP tax data

  • Duplicate check does not trigger during Save

  • No error or warning message is shown

Questions

  1. How do we configure GST-specific duplicate checks in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?

  2. Which app or configuration controls duplicate detection for Business Partners?

  3. Is GSTIN-based duplicate prevention supported in Public Cloud?

  4. Are there any known limitations or SAP Notes related to this?

Regards,

Siva.

entry.title: Inbound Interface: EDI ‚Üí SAP BTP (Integration Suite with TPM) ‚Üí SAP S/4HANA (via IDoc) for B2B
entry.content:
This Blog will guide you to set up an inbound EDI-to-IDOC integration using SAP BTP‚Äôs Trading Partner Management (TPM). It involves creating company and partner profiles, defining identifiers, systems, and communications, then configuring agreements and mapping to route EDI messages through BTP IS to SAP S/4HANA via IDOC.

Step 0: Create MIG

0.1: Create a MIG in your Integration Advisor as per below details and use that MIG in the steps 3.2 and 4.3 and refresh & save it.

Step 1: Create Company Profile

Create a new Company for ‚ÄúCPI‚Äù.

Note: Only 1 Company Profile can exist per tenant.

1.1: Navigate to the Design tab, choose the B2B Scenario, then select Company Profile within TPM (Trading Partner Management), and click the Create profile button.

Provide Company Name and short name then save it.

1.2: Create Identifier in above company which you have created, in the right side there is Identifier tab at top. You can have as many Identifiers for your Company as you want. In our case we have to create 2 Identifiers for our company, one is for SAP S4 and another for EDI.

Note: for EDI, check Custom Scheme as per EDI and provide Scheme code and Scheme Name as per requirement.

1.3: Go to the Systems Tab of created Company and Create a System.

Click on + button to create new Type.

1.4: Select/Click on above system which you have created, in that new option will open in right side as Create Type System.

Note: The Version of System should match the DOCREL in your EDI Control Record (EDI_DC40) from your IDOC, so please provide the same version which is available in IDOC.

1.5: Select Communication as per the below image and create it.

As we are going to map the EDI file to an IDOC and post it to SAP S4, we need to define a Receiver Communication for our Company. Provide all IDOC details and save it.

 

Step 2: Create Trading Partners

2.1: Go to your Trading Partner Management (B2B Scenarios) in Design and select Partner Profile Tab. Click on Create Trading Partner and provide all details.

2.2: Create Identifiers for above Trading Partner which we have created.

Note: Refer 1.2 for details.

2.3: Create a System for Trading Partner which you have created. Go to the Systems Tab of created Trading Partner and Create a System.

Note: Refer 1.3 for more details.

2.4: Select/Click on above system which you have created, in that new option will open in right side as Create Type System.

Create a Type System for the Trading Partner with the details.

Note: Refer 1.4 for details.

2.5: Create Communication for Trading Partner.

As we will receive the EDI File from our trading partner (HF) from SFTP, we will need to create a Sender Communication for this Trading Partner in TPM. 

Step 3: Define Agreement Template

3.1: We will create an Agreement Template in our Trading Partner Management. The Agreement Template here is where CUSTOMER1 is the Initiator and SAPS4Hana200 is the Reactor.

Select Agreement Templates in Trading Partner Management and click on create button.

3.2: Select MIG if you have created.

3.3: Define the Communication channel (IDoc) in your Template and save it.

Step 4: Define Agreement

4.1: Create an Agreement in your Trading Partner Management as per below details.

You will now see D.96B.S3 in your Trading Partner Agreement. Select that and the remaining Identifiers as per screenshot below.

4.2: Provide Sender Communication Details in Trading Partner Agreement. Select Sender Communication.

Select Communication and save it.

4.3: Provide Sender Interchange Details in Trading Partner Agreement.

Choose MIG and save it.

4.4: Provide Mapping Details in Trading Partner Agreement.

Note: As per our scope, we will not use MAG and use a Message Mapping in Cloud Integration. Select option ‚ÄúCustomized Mapping Processing‚Äù and provide your Process Direct endpoint of your Iflow (/tpm/Customer1/EDIFACT_ORDERSD86B/IDOC_ORDERS_ORDERS05). Note this endpoint as you will use it in the next step.

4.5: Activate your Trading Partner Agreement.

 

Conclusion:

By following these steps, you can successfully set up an inbound EDI-to-IDOC integration using SAP BTP‚Äôs Trading Partner Management (TPM). The process involves creating company and partner profiles, defining identifiers and systems, configuring communications, and establishing agreements. Leveraging MIG for message structure and customized mapping in Cloud Integration ensures that EDI messages are accurately transformed and routed to SAP S/4HANA via IDoc. This approach provides a standardized, scalable, and efficient way to manage B2B integrations on SAP BTP.

entry.title: Re: Indirect tax for plants abroad with a permanent establishement
entry.content: Indirect tax treatment for plants abroad with a permanent establishment (PE) generally requires the foreign plant to be treated as a separate taxable entity in that jurisdiction. This means VAT, excise, or other indirect taxes must be registered and reported locally, rather than consolidated under the parent company.

entry.title: How to retain cohort membership history when learners are relegated to a new cohort?
entry.content:
Scenario
We manage class cohorts and sometimes learners are relegated (moved to a different cohort due to performance or compliance).

Problem
When a learner is removed from their previous cohort and added to a new one, the old record disappears. We lose the history of cohort membership and the dates of when they were in the previous cohort.

Requirement
We need a way to:

  • Retain historical cohort membership (with start/end dates).
  • Report both current cohort and past cohorts for each learner.

    Questions

    1. Is there a standard configuration or report that supports this?
    2. Can we enable audit trail or effective dating for cohort membership?
    3. If not, what‚Äôs the best approach to implement this (custom table, integration, or reporting workaround)?

entry.title: Re: Unexpected document Split Clearing Account
entry.content: Hi, The behavior you're observing is always happening and is working as designed. FI direct postings to WBS elements will consistently generate document split clearing account 29500100 due to dimensional balancing requirements, while CO activity allocations will not trigger this clearing account usage. This difference is fundamental to how S/4HANA handles FI versus CO postings and should be expected in all similar scenarios. If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better. Br.Bob

entry.title: How to apply a dynamic discount (Z-table) to interest items in ECC 6.0 without separate credit memos
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I am facing a major technical blocker in ECC 6.0 EHP8 (FI-CA 618 / IS-U active). We need to apply a dynamic discount from a Z-table (Doc Type + Installment count) to the final interest amount in FPR1.

What we have already exhausted:

1. Event 2085: Blocked by STAKZ (Taxes). Cannot use it when tax indicators are present.

2. Note 902456: Subroutine for v_zins only triggers with RFKN1-GZVER active, and even then, the OLD_INTEREST vs NEW_INTEREST comparison fails, causing a consistency error.

3. Events 0350 / 2095: Manual changes to T_FKKIA or FKKOP are either overwritten or rejected by the core calculation engine.

4. Implicit Enhancements: We have analyzed the call stack from ADD_INTEREST_AND_FEE down to FKK_INTEREST_CALC. We couldn't find a viable enhancement point that allows us to bypass the final validation without modifying the standard.

The Question: Since we cannot find an enhancement point or a standard event that works with taxes and passes the consistency check, how can we persist a discounted interest amount? Is there any "hidden" way to influence the calculation parameters so the ACxx rules "believe" the discounted amount is the correct one? Or is it technically impossible in ECC 6.18 to adjust the interest amount without a separate credit memo?

entry.title: Re: Stock & Quality Management by Handling Unit (Bags / P...
entry.content:
Good day @c_walid 

Thank you for your question

In summary, the answer to whether you can use Handling Unit as a business stock and inspection dimension e.g., for bags, pallets not only as a packaging object in public cloud will depend on whether you stay in Inventory Management only or if you are using Warehouse Management capabilities.

Let us look at what you can do in regard to:

Stock visibility by bags or pallets:

  • So, the answer to your question is, yes, you can list and analyse stock by Handling Unit when you make use of the standard HU monitoring apps, which enables you to see how many pallets exist as number of HUs. However, standard stock overview apps by default are still quantity based or alternative UoM and not counted by HU. See Handling Unit Management and Handling Units in Cloud Processes for more details.

Physical inventory by pallet or by bag:

  • In inventory management only, physical inventory is fundamentally quantity based. Which means you can count in UoM. See Handling Units in Inventory Management and Manage Physical Inventory Documents for more insights.
  • If you were to use Warehouse Management, you can run warehouse processes where Hus are handled explicitly, including HU focused operational steps.

Handling Unit Quality inspection:

  • In public Cloud, quality execution for HU is mainly supported when you use Warehouse Management integration with QM rather than only inspecting lot per HU as the primary object. See Quality Management in Warehousing and Warehouse Internal Inspections for some details.
  • The classical Quality Inspection for Handling Units is clearly documented here for on premise.

 

My workaround recommendations are as follows:

  • For bag or pallet stock analysis: Make use of Monitor Handling Units for HU counts and Stock Single Material for quantity totals. See Monitor Handling Units for more details.
  • If you want inventory by bag or pallet without EWM, I suggest you use Alternative UoM (BAG, PAL) and count in that UoM.
  • If you want HU selective quality control, then use warehouse inspection and stock status flows to isolate and manage only your affected Hus
  • If your requirement is strict HU based inspection lots and UDs, you can validate whether you need Private Cloud or On Prem QM HU inspection scope.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Tricentis integration with Cloud ALM for Test automation
entry.content:
This integration combines the application lifecycle management capabilities of SAP Cloud ALM with the test automation capabilities of Tricentis, allowing you to design automated, functional, end-to-end software tests and manage them with test orchestration, execution monitoring, and reporting capabilities.

Let's start with SAP Cloud ALM tenant.

1. Add New Service in Cloud ALM

  • Log in to your Cloud ALM tenant
  • Navigate to: Administration ‚Üí Landscape Management ‚Üí Services & Systems ‚Üí Add ‚Üí New Service

Enter the following details:

  • Name: (Your preferred name)
  • System Number: (Any value)
  • Role: Test
  • Service Type: Tricentis
  • Deployment Model: SAP Public Cloud
  •  Root URL:  Add _sap-integration at the end of your tricentis URL.

Save your changes and proceed to the Endpoints section.

2. Configure Endpoints

  • Root URL: Same as above
  • Authentication Type: OAuth credentials

3. Retrieve OAuth Credentials

To find the Client ID and Client Secret:  

  •  Use  _identity/apiDocs/swagger/index.html as extension to your tricentis URL and login to Tricentis account.
  • Click on Authorize button and then click on Get.

  • Use GET /_identity/api/v1/applications to obtain the Application (Client) ID for Tricentis Cloud API

Click on Try it out and Execute 

Scroll down till Response Body and Search for 

"name": "Tricentis Cloud API"

Copy the Application ID.

  • For Client Secret: Use GET /_identity/api/v1/applications/{id}/secrets (replace {id} with your Application ID). Application ID can be fetched from Get: Applications.

Click on Try it out and add application ID fetched from previous step, Click on Execute.

In Response Body you will find Client ID and Client Secret. 

 

4. Token Secure URL

  • From your Tricentis home page, navigate to your profile and Click on edit profile in Okta

  • Copy the URL up to .com, then add /oauth2/default/v1/token to the end

  • Use this as the Token Secure URL and check the connection.

Once the connection is successfully established, you‚Äôll be able to import and execute Tricentis test cases directly within SAP Cloud ALM.

You can try this in SAP Cloud ALM Demo Tenant using Tricentis Cloud trail version. 

Conclusion: 

By successfully integrating SAP Cloud ALM with Tricentis, organizations can significantly streamline their end-to-end application lifecycle and testing processes. This combined solution empowers teams to design, orchestrate, and manage automated test cases directly within SAP Cloud ALM, leveraging Tricentis‚Äôs powerful test automation capabilities.

SAP Cloud ALM

entry.title: Re: Disable Create Action in Manage Supplier Master Data...
entry.content:
Good day @sandeep_shankarampet 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, yes, your observation on Adapt UI hiding the Create button globally is correct and is therefore not a role-based authorisation control. In public cloud, the supported way you can control Create is through authorisation. See Configuring Business Roles for more details.

In public cloud you can prevent creation for specific roles by removing Create Suppler authorisation from those roles. The button will typically be disabled, or the action will be rejected by the backend. See Maintain Business Roles for more insights.

The public cloud does not provide the option, from a clean core perspective, to use Adapt UI to remove the create button for only some roles. Reason is, it impacts all users of that adaptation layer. See Adapting the UI for more information.

All three roles you mentioned likely include one or more business catalogs that grant Supplier Create authorisation for the app, which is likely the root cause. In public cloud you do not maintain authorisation objects directly rather you control it through catalog assignment and release restriction.

 

In your tenant, you need to identify which catalog grants Create for this app.

  • Go to IAM Information System, search for Manage Supplier Master Data (F1053A). Use the IAM details to determine which business catalogs are required for the app and which authorisations are linked to create vs change.

  • Next you need to split the business roles by capability (between Create and Non create). For the two roles that must not create; open Maintain Business Roles, then open Role A (no create) √† Assigned Business Catalogs, remove the catalog identified in Step 1 that provide create supplier capability. Keep only catalogs that provide display if you require.

  • Repeat the same process for Role B
  • For the one role that you want to have the create functionality, open Role C and ensure it contains catalogs that provide the create capability.
  • Finally, you should validate your changes by login in with users A, B and C to confirm your modifications.

Note that the restriction fields you see in Maintain Business Roles are mainly for data visibility and organisational filtering, not for you to hide UI actions like Create. You can control actions through delivered catalogs. See Data Visibility Based on Restrictions and Maintain Business Roles for more information.

If you require the button to be removed and not just disabled, as a workaround, you can provide a separate tile or app approach for those roles while you keep the F1053A for creators or accept disable Create for non creator roles.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 1

Introduction

SAP Joule enables users to interact with enterprise data using natural language, turning complex analytics into actionable insights. When integrated with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) through SAP Build Work Zone, Joule becomes a powerful interface for consuming analytical content securely and seamlessly.

In this blog we will start the integration step-by-step including subaccount setup, identity provisioning, destination configuration, SAP Build Work Zone setup, and SAP Analytics Cloud integration.

Prerequisites

Before starting the integration, ensure the following foundational setup is completed. These steps establish the required SAP BTP subaccounts, spaces, and identity services used throughout the configuration.

1. Create the Main BTP Subaccount for Joule and Work Zone

This subaccount hosts SAP Build Work Zone, Joule, and runtime configurations.

  1. Create a new SAP BTP Subaccount
    Example name:    JouleBATTesting

  2. Enable the Cloud Foundry environment for the subaccount.
  3. Within the subaccount, create a Cloud Foundry Space:
    Example: JouleSpace
  4. Leave all checkboxes at their default values during space creation.

2. Create a Dedicated Subaccount for Identity Provisioning (IdP)

A separate subaccount is recommended for managing identity provisioning and synchronization across systems.

  1. Create a new SAP BTP Subaccount
    Example name: JouleIDP
  2. Enable the Cloud Foundry environment.
  3. Create a Cloud Foundry Space:
    Example: JouleIDPSpace

3. Enable Cloud Identity Services in the IdP Subaccount

  1. In the JouleIDP subaccount, navigate to:
    Entitlements ‚Üí Configure Entitlements

  2. Add the following service:
    Service: Cloud Identity Services
    Plan: additional-tenant (Application)
  3. Save the entitlement configuration.

4. Create or Subscribe to Cloud Identity Services

You can create the service either from the Service Marketplace or Instances and Subscriptions.

Option A: Using Service Marketplace

  1. Go to Service Marketplace.

  2. Search for Cloud Identity Services.
  3. Select Service Plans and choose additional-tenant.
  4. Assign the service to the space JouleIDPSpace (if not already created).
  5. Create a new instance or subscription.
Option B: Using Instances and Subscriptions

  1. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions ‚Üí Create.

  2. Select:
    Service: Cloud Identity Services
    Plan: additional-tenant
  3. Click Next.
  4. Choose:
    Service Type: TEST (or as per your landscape requirement)
  5. Complete the creation.

Configure Trust and Enable SAP Build Work Zone

All steps below are performed in the JouleBATTesting subaccount.

5. Establish Trust with the Identity Provider

To allow users provisioned through IPS to authenticate correctly, trust must be established.

Procedure

  1. Go to Security ‚Üí Trust Configuration

  2. Choose Establish Trust
  3. Select the custom IdP created earlier
  4. Click Next ‚Üí Finish

‚úî Trust is now established between the Joule subaccount and the IdP.

6. Generate Destination Trust

  1. Navigate to Connectivity ‚Üí Destination Trust

  2. Click Generate Trust

This enables secure communication between destinations and subscribed services.

7. Assign SAP Build Work Zone Entitlements

Procedure

  1. Go to Entitlements ‚Üí Configure Entitlements

  2. Search for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition
  3. Select the following service plans:
    standard
    standard (Application)
  4. Click Add Service Plans and Save

8. Subscribe to SAP Build Work Zone

  1. Navigate to Services ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions

  2. Under Subscriptions, choose Create
  3. Select:
    Service: SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition
    Plan: standard
  4. Click Create

9. Create SAP Build Work Zone Instance

  1. In Instances, click Create

  2. Provide the following values:
    Runtime Environment: Cloud Foundry
    Space: JouleSpace
    Instance Name: SWZJoule (user-defined)
  3. Click Next ‚Üí Finish

10. Create and Download the Service Key

  1. Open the instance SWZJoule

  2. From the three-dot menu (‚ãÆ), choose Create Service Key
  3. Enter:
    Service Key Name: SWZInstanceKey
  4. Create the key and download the JSON file

This file will be used later for destination and IPS configuration.

11. Import Navigation Service Destination

This destination enables navigation between SAP Build Work Zone and Joule.

Procedure

  1. Navigate to Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations (Legacy)

  2. Choose Import Destination
  3. Import the provided template:
    NavigationService-TEMPL
  4. Update the destination properties using values from the service key:

    PropertyValue
    NameNavigationService
    URLPortal URL from service key JSON
    Client IDclientid
    Client Secretclientsecret
    Token Service URL<url>/token
  5. Save the destination

Enable Joule and Run the Joule Booster

12. Assign Joule Services (BTP Control Center)

  1. Open SAP BTP Control Center

  2. From the three-dot menu (‚ãÆ), select Assign Services
  3. Search for Joule
  4. Select:
    Joule Internal Production | das-application-canary
  5. Click Next
  6. Expand Joule Internal Production
  7. Select plans:
    development
    standard
  8. Set Quota to 5 (or as required)
  9. Click Save

13. Register SAP Cloud Identity System

  1. From the Global Account, go to Systems

  2. Add the SAP Cloud Identity system using Service Owner View
  3. Navigate to Entitlements ‚Üí Service Assignments
  4. Refresh the page

14. Run the Joule Booster

  1. In the Global Account, search for Joule

  2. Go to Boosters ‚Üí Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)
  3. Click Start
  4. Wait for Check Prerequisites to complete successfully
  5. Click Next

Subaccount Setup

  • Plan: standard (das-application-canary)
  • Subaccount: JouleBATTesting

Integration Setup

  • Products:
      SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition
      SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Integration Purpose: Testing

6. Complete the booster execution

‚úî Required formations and baseline integration are now created.

For further configuration refer
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 2

entry.title: How to calculate Supplier Evaluation by Time score, based on updated delivery date
entry.content:
Standard SAP behaviour is to calculate Supplier Evaluation by Time score, based on original delivery date. How can we change this to updated delivery date?




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to calculate Supplier Evaluation by Time score, b...
entry.content:
Dear Customer

I am afraid to say that in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the Supplier Evaluation ‚Äì Delivery Time scoring is calculated based on the original purchase order delivery date. The system does not provide standard functionality to calculate scores using updated delivery dates.

Key Points:

  • This is standard SAP behavior and cannot be changed via configuration in the cloud.

  • As a workaround, you may consider:

    1. Manual adjustments before running supplier evaluation reports, ensuring delivery dates reflect actual expectations.

    2. Custom reporting or analytics (for example, using SAP Analytics Cloud or CDS views) to calculate scores based on updated delivery dates.

We understand that scoring based on updated delivery dates would be more meaningful for your business processes and recommend raising an enhancement request via SAP Customer Influence for future releases.

Kind regards,
Aishwarya

LTMC (Legacy Transfer Migration Cockpit) as a transaction code/tool used in older SAP S/4HANA releases still technically exists for read/display of existing projects, but its use is deprecated for creating new migration projects.

‚ú≥Ô∏è The new Fiori-based ‚ÄúMigrate Your Data ‚Äì Migration Cockpit‚Äù has replaced LTMC for actual data migration tasks in modern SAP S/4HANA (Cloud and On-Premise).

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 2

Introduction

In Part 1, we completed the foundational setup for SAP Joule by:

  • Creating SAP BTP subaccounts and spaces
  • Configuring SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enabling SAP Build Work Zone
  • Running the Joule Booster to establish system formations

In Part 2, we complete the integration by connecting SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to SAP Build Work Zone and Joule. This includes:

  • OAuth client creation in SAC
  • Design-time and runtime destination configuration
  • Content provider creation
  • Role consumption
  • User and role provisioning using Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)
  • Final Joule validation

Create OAuth Clients in SAP Analytics Cloud

To allow SAP Build Work Zone and Joule to securely access SAP Analytics Cloud content, OAuth clients must be configured in SAC.

SAP documentation reference:
Consume Role Definition Content from SAP Analytics Cloud

1. Create OAuth Client for Design-Time Access

The design-time OAuth client is used to:

  • Read SAC role definitions
  • Import analytical metadata into SAP Build Work Zone

Procedure

  1. Log in to SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Navigate to:
    System ‚Üí Administration ‚Üí App Integration
  3. Under Configured Clients, choose Add an OAuth Client
  4. Maintain the following values:
    Name: sac-buildworkzone-dt (example)
    Purpose: API Access
    Access: User Provisioning
    Authorization Grant: Client Credentials
  5. Configure Token Lifetime:
    Positive integer value
    Units: minutes, hours, or days
    If not specified, the token lifetime is infinite
  6. Click Add

Save Credentials

  • Copy and store the Client ID
  • Click Copy Secret and save the Client Secret
  • Note the Token Service URL

Important
The client secret is displayed only once and cannot be retrieved later.

OAuth Clients Summary

After completing this step, you should have two OAuth clients in SAP Analytics Cloud:

1. Runtime OAuth Client (Auto-created by Joule Booster)

  • Created automatically during Joule booster execution
  • Used at runtime by Joule
  • Uses SAML Bearer Assertion
  • Client secret cannot be copied

2. Design-Time OAuth Client (Manually Created)

  • Used for:
    Importing SAC roles
    Reading analytical metadata
  • Client ID and secret are used in SAP BTP destinations

Create Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

This destination enables SAP Build Work Zone to read role definitions from SAP Analytics Cloud.

Procedure

  1. Sign in to the JouleBATTesting subaccount
  2. Navigate to:
    Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations
  3. Click Create Destination

Destination Configuration

PropertyValue
NameSAC_SWZ_DT
TypeHTTP
URLhttps://<SAC-domain>/api/v1/cdm
Proxy TypeInternet
AuthenticationOAuth2ClientCredentials
Client IDSAC design-time OAuth Client ID
Client SecretSAC design-time OAuth Client Secret
Token Service URL TypeDedicated
Token Service URL Token URL from SAC OAuth configuration

Additional Properties

PropertyValue
HTML5.SetXForwardedHeadersfalse
URL.headers.x-sap-sac-custom-auth true

4. Click Save

Create Runtime Destination by Cloning

Instead of manually creating a runtime destination, reuse the destination created automatically by the Joule booster.

Procedure

  1. Go to:
    Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations
  2. Locate destination:
    DYN_SAC_SSO
  3. Click Clone
  4. Provide a new name:
    SAC_SWZ_RT

Additional Properties

PropertyValue
sap-card-nominations-path/api/v1/interest-cards
sap-start true
 
5. Save the destination



Assign Required Roles to Users

Before proceeding, ensure the user has required roles.

Procedure

  1. Go to:
    Subaccount ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Users
  2. Assign the following roles to the IdP user:
    Launchpad_Admin
    Launchpad_External_User

Create Content Provider in SAP Build Work Zone

This step imports SAC content and role definitions into SAP Build Work Zone.

Procedure

  1. Go to Service Marketplace
  2. Open SAP Build Work Zone
  3. Choose Go to Application
  4. Navigate to Channel Manager
  5. Click + New Content Provider

Content Provider Configuration

PropertyValue
Titlesac.analytics
DescriptionSAP Analytics Cloud content
IDsac.analytics
Design-Time DestinationSAC_SWZ_DT
Runtime DestinationSAC_SWZ_RT
Runtime Destination for Dynamic DataDefault
Automatically add contentEnabled
Use IPS for authorizationsEnabled

6. Click Save

Results

  • SAC role definitions are imported into SAP Build Work Zone
  • System Owner role is intentionally not imported
  • Role changes in SAC require manual refresh from Channel Manager

Provision Users Using Identity Provisioning Service (IPS)

To allow users to access analytical insights via Joule, users, roles, and permissions must be synced from SAC to SAP Build Work Zone.

1. Configure SAP Analytics Cloud as Source System

Reference: SAP Analytics Cloud IPS documentation

Procedure

  1. Open SAP Cloud Identity Services Admin Console
  2. Navigate to:
    Identity Provisioning ‚Üí Source Systems
  3. Add SAP Analytics Cloud as a source system

Mandatory Properties

PropertyValue
TypeHTTP
URLSAC base URL (no path)
ProxyTypeInternet
AuthenticationBasicAuthentication
UserSAC OAuth Client ID
PasswordSAC OAuth Client Secret
OAuth2TokenServiceURLSAC token service URL
sac.api.version2 (recommended)




2. Configure Transformations

  • Navigate to Transformations
  • Paste the JSON from:
    Default transformation for SAP Analytics Cloud SCIM API v2

3. Configure SAP Build Work Zone as Target System

Reference: SAP Build Work Zone IPS documentation

  • Use the service key JSON from SWZInstanceKey
  • Configure:
    API URL
    OAuth client ID
    OAuth client secret
  • Use default transformation from SAP documentation





Run Provisioning Jobs

Simulate Provisioning

  1. Go to SAC Source System ‚Üí Jobs
  2. Click Run Now on Simulate Job
  3. Verify logs:
    Identity Provisioning ‚Üí Provisioning Logs

‚úî No errors should appear

Execute Provisioning

  1. Run Read Job
  2. Check provisioning logs again

Validate User Provisioning

  1. Log in to SAP Build Work Zone as Launchpad_Admin
  2. Go to:
    Settings ‚Üí Identity Provisioning
  3. Enter SAC user email
  4. Validate role IDs are correctly assigned

Create Joule User Role Collection

Procedure

  1. Create User (ex - testuser@test.com)
  2. Go to JouleBATTesting ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Role Collections
  3. Create role collection:
    Joule_User
  4. Add:
    Joule roles
    Launchpad_Admin (if site admin access is required)
  5. Assign role collection to IdP users
  6. Log out and log back in









Index Data Using Just Ask and Validate Joule

Reference: SAP Joule documentation

Important Validation Rules

  • SAC models must:
    Belong to the same user
    Be indexed under Just Ask using the same identity
  • Example user:
    testuser@test.com

If models are indexed under a different user, Joule will not return results.





SAP Analytics Cloud Integration into Joule - Part 1

Reference Link
https://help.sap.com/doc/de3af3c0f81642dbaa4d36172ed57a72/CLOUD/en-US/79bfc83ab386450c8cd9c7937ce26a3a.pdf

Thanks
Ashraf

entry.title: Re: Auto extend plant to a material SAP MDG
entry.content:
Hello,

Please make sure to keep the below points into your design consideration -

  • Wrap your code in an update function module with delayed run. 
  • Using Governance API to create a follow up CR is a right approach with additional enhancement of the data but you have to make sure to use the governance API in the right way, for example, locking the main entity, writing the entity data and triggering the workflow using the API.
  • Consider adding an application log for follow up CR creation to log the errors and success messages to ensure that your design is robust and any production issue can be easily checked.
  • Here is the document that you can refer for the technical frameworks of the SAP MDG APIs which will help you writing your code - https://www.sap.com/documents/2015/07/666e4158-5b7c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Regards,

Saikat.

entry.title: FREIGHT COST (Planned Delivery costs)
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I have a procurement scenario related to delivery costs with a different freight vendor, and I would appreciate your guidance on how this can be handled in standard SAP.

I created a Purchase Order for 100 quantities with planned delivery costs, where the freight vendor is different from the material supplier.

Process executed:

  1. The first partial Goods Receipt was posted for 50 quantities, followed by:
    • Invoice posting for the material supplier
    • Invoice posting for the freight (delivery cost) supplier
  2. During the second partial delivery for the remaining 50 quantities, the freight supplier and freight charges are different from the first delivery.

Issue faced:

  • There is no option to change the freight vendor or delivery cost values at PO level for the second delivery.
  • When attempting to change the freight vendor during invoice posting, the system throws an error stating that the Invoicing Party is different.
  • This blocks invoice posting for the new freight supplier.

Business concern:
From a business perspective, this is a common scenario in international procurement, where:

  • Each shipment or partial delivery may have a different freight forwarder
  • Freight charges may vary for every delivery

Question:
How can this scenario be handled in a standard SAP way without customization?

  • Is there a recommended process or configuration to manage multiple freight vendors across partial deliveries?
  • What is the SAP best practice for such international procurement scenarios?

Best Regards,

Dinesh U

entry.title: Re: Call derivations on custom event in sap mdg
entry.content:
Hello @VISHAL_JHA , your requirement appears to be a classic application for SAP MDG's enrichment framework. I believe utilizing this framework would be beneficial for your needs, as it is commonly employed in most implementation projects

Should you wish to trigger it consistently, you could consider invoking it within the derivation BADI. However, please be aware that this approach may incur additional costs due to frequent triggering during refresh events. Also note that this can be controlled if you wish to trigger it using a specific button by instantiating CL_FPM and CL_FPM_EVENT to read the current event that triggers while the user clicks the button.

My recommendation would be to trigger the API in a more controlled manner using the SAP MDG's enrichment framework.

Regards

Saikat.

entry.title: How to Access SAP Cloud Logging Service Dashboards Using IAS SAML Authentication
entry.content:
Japanese version

Introduction

SAP Cloud Logging Service (CLS) is an OpenSearch-based observability service that allows you to centrally manage application logs and metrics.

Because CLS Dashboards provide access to application data such as logs and metrics, proper security measures such as authentication methods and access control are essential.

Although CLS Dashboards can be accessed using a Service Key, SAP recommends using SAML authentication with IAS in production environments to ensure proper user management and stronger security.

In this article, we walk through the configuration steps required to enable SAML authentication for CLS Dashboards using IAS.

Prerequisites

This guide assumes the following conditions are met:

  • An IAS tenant is active
  • SAP Cloud Logging Service is available in your SAP BTP subaccount
  • You have administrator privileges for both IAS and the BTP subaccount

Step 1: Create a SAML 2.0 Application in IAS

In the IAS administration application, navigate to Applications & Resources ‚Üí Applications, and create a new application.

  • Display Name: Any name
  • Protocol Type: SAML 2.0

Step 2: Create a CLS Instance and Configure SAML

If you already have an existing CLS instance, you can update its parameters in the same way as during instance creation.

In this article, we describe the steps using a new CLS instance.

2-1. Create a CLS Instance

Create a CLS instance in your BTP subaccount.

  • Service: Cloud Logging
  • Plan / Runtime Environment: Choose according to your use case
  • Instance Name: Any name

After entering the values, click Next to proceed to the parameter configuration screen.

2-2. Configure SAML Parameters

The default parameters will be displayed. Edit the saml section as shown below.

Default parameters

Updated parameters

{
  "saml": {
    "enabled": true,
    "admin_group": "<IAS_ADMIN_GROUP_NAME>",
    "initiated": true,
    "roles_key": "groups",
    "idp": {
      "metadata_url": "<IAS_TENANT_URL>/saml2/metadata",
      "entity_id": "<IAS_IDP_ENTITY_ID>"
    },
    "sp": {
      "entity_id": "<CLS_SP_ENTITY_ID>"
    }
  }
}

saml section template

Parameter Explanation

admin_group
Users who belong to the specified IAS group are granted administrator privileges (all_access).
In this example, we use cls-admin.

idp.metadata_url
The URL from which CLS retrieves SAML metadata from IAS.
Append /saml2/metadata to your IAS tenant URL.
For example, if your IAS tenant URL is:
https://<YOUR-TENANT-NAME>.accounts400.ondemand.com

then set:
https://<YOUR-TENANT-NAME>.accounts400.ondemand.com/saml2/metadata

idp.entity_id
Open the metadata_url in a browser and set the value of 'entityID' found at the beginning of the XML.

sp.entity_id
The identifier for CLS as a Service Provider. In this example, we use 'CLS-Demo'. The same value must be configured on the IAS side.

Step 3: Configure SAML Settings in IAS

In the IAS application settings, select Configure Manually and configure the SAML settings.

  • Entity ID: Same value as 'sp.entity_id' of the CLS instance

This ID uniquely identifies CLS as the Service Provider in the SAML integration.
Since we used 'CLS-Demo'in the CLS configuration, the same value must be set here.

Endpoint Configuration

  • SSO Endpoint: <Dashboards URL>/_opendistro/_security/saml/acs

  • Single Logout Endpoint: <Dashboards URL>

Verification (Authentication)

Access the CLS Dashboards URL and confirm that authentication succeeds.

At this point, when opening dashboards or index lists, you may see a blank page or permission-related errors.

In Developer Tools, you can also confirm that HTTP 403 (Forbidden) responses are returned.

If you click View roles and identities from the user icon, you will see that only the 'own_index' role is assigned.

This indicates that SAML authentication is working correctly, but authorization (role assignment) has not yet been configured.

Step 4: Configure Attributes in the IAS Application

To use IAS group information for role assignment in CLS, group data must be included in the SAML assertion.

Open Attributes in the IAS application and configure the following:

  • Name: groups
  • Source: Identity Directory
  • Values: All Groups

Step 5: Create a Group and Add Users

Create a user group in IAS with the same name as the 'admin_group' configured in Step 2.
In this example, the group name is 'cls-admin'.

  • Name: Same as 'admin_group'

  • Display Name: Any name

Add the target users to the group.

 

Verification (Authorization)

Access the dashboard page again and confirm that the list of dashboard is now visible.

You can also verify that the 'all_access' role has been assigned to the user via the 'cls_admin' group.


I hope this article helps you with application development and operations on SAP BTP!!

References

  • https://docs.opensearch.org/latest/security/authentication-backends/saml/
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/prerequisites
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/configuration-parameters

entry.title: Re: Posting type 4 or 5 in electronic bank statement - ba...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

Account symbols are only evaluated in posting area 1 of transaction OT83.

  • Posting area 1 ‚Üí determines which G/L account is posted

  • Posting area 2 ‚Üí used for clearing logic, not for account determination

For posting types 4 and 5 (G/L postings), SAP:

  • Posts the bank clearing account in posting area 1

  • Does NOT automatically copy that account into AVKON / AGKON

  • Leaves FEBEP-AVKON / FEBCL-AGKON empty unless something explicitly fills it

This is by design.

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha

entry.title: Re: Track & report reasons for component shortages/spills...
entry.content:
Good day @FaisalMaayeh 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, yes, in public cloud you can capture and report a reason for an additional component issue to a production order. The best way is to use the Reason for Movement on the goods movement type 261 to a production order.

Using the standard analytics for goods movement where Reason for Movement is an available dimension provides you the possibility to report and trend these postings. See Goods Movement Analysis for more details.

Please not that the Reason for Movement field is not always shown for every movement type or in every posting unless you enabled it in your configuration.  See KBA 2865146 and 2596465 for more insights.

Here is a guidance for your tenant:

First, you need to maintain your reason codes list, from which your users can choose. Open your Central Business Configuration or your configuration app. Search for Reason for Movement and maintain your reason codes such as 001 spillage, 002 Damaged during transport, 003 Quantity short at line, etc and save.

Second, you must ensure that you enabled the 261 for the Reason for Movement. If your users receive an error ‚ÄúA reason has to be entered‚Äù but cannot see the filed, then your config is correct. See KBA 2865146 and 3697643 for more details.

Third, open Post Goods Movement app that your process uses, post a goods issue with reference to the production order and the component material (movement type 261). In the item details, maintain Reason for Movement with the correct code and post.

Next is to create reports and analytics for trends. For this, you use option A standard analytics. Open Goods Movement Analysis, filter by date range, plant, material and movement type 261.  Add or group by Reason for Movement (which you have maintained during the first step). You can carry out further drilldowns to the material document and production order for more traceability. See Goods Movement Analysis for more details.

Or option B, create a Custom Analytical Query on a material document-based data source.

Include fields such as Production order, material, posting date, movement type, quantity and reason for movement.

Add filters for plant, storage location, production order range and reason code. Then export the result if you need.

Go to Display, Put calendar first in Rows, then Reason for Movement, add any options you need and save.

Then publish, run and export the data.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Enable Widget Busy Indicator / Ghost Loading indicator for Custom Widgets in SAP Analytics Cl
entry.content:
Hello,

We have created a Bar + Line chart custom widget using Chart.js in SAP Analytics Cloud (Optimized Story Experience).

We want to display the SAC busy indicator whenever the user interacts with the custom widget (for example, on data refresh, filter change, or other interactions).

As per the Custom Widget Developer Guide, custom widgets support viewport loading in the optimized story experience by enabling the following property in the widget JSON:

 

 
"supportsViewportLoading": true

We have enabled this property in our widget JSON. However, when interacting with the widget in view mode, the busy indicator is not shown.

Questions

  1. Is enabling  "supportsViewportLoading": true alone sufficient to trigger the busy indicator?

  2. Do we also need to explicitly fire the customWidgetRenderComplete event, and if so, when exactly should it be fired (after DOM render, after data binding, or after Chart.js rendering)?

  3. Are there any working examples or reference implementations for using viewport loading with custom widgets

  4. If viewport loading does not trigger the busy indicator for interactions, is there any recommended workaround to show a busy indicator for custom widgets?
     

Any guidance or examples would be greatly appreciated.

SAP Analytics Cloud #customwidget #SAC #Chart.js 

#Optimized Story Experience  #JavaScript

@Meet_Patel10    @dishantp40 @Chandra_Bhansali

entry.title: How to maintain multiple address in public cloud? In On promise using the T.code: MEAN

entry.title: Route Train operation for Inbound processes
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing logistics 2310 FPS01 we have enhanced the list of processes which are covered by route train with the following entities:

  • Inbound deliveries
  • Warehouse task without Warehouse request
  • Outbound deliveries for Plant maintenance orders

The following blog will describe the required setup for an inbound delivery-related route train scenario.

Background

Inbound processes are supported with SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics in 2 ways:

  • Inbound deliveries from Goods receipt from Production
  • Inbound deliveries from external vendors

Inbound deliveries from Production support the putaway of HUs from a production line back to the warehouse while inbound deliveries from external vendors either supply the production itself or can be used to putaway received HUs into the warehouse.

Goods receipt from Production

Production processes need to be set up in advance and we use in this scenario a manufacturing order, which has been created upfront. 

You can e.g. post receipt of HUs based on a manufacturing order. The receipt of Hus can be performed e.g. via RF in SAP EWM with the logical transaction for Receiving of HUs by Manufacturing Order..

You logon to a suitable workcenter and then enter the manufacturing order.

Figure 1: Enter your Manufacturing Order in RF

With the manufacturing order input you need to verify the produced product. When you create an HU, the system automatically creates an inbound delivery for the HU.

Figure 2: Create a new HU in RF 

Figure 3: Created inbound delivery with determined route on item level

This inbound delivery then determines automatically a route based on the condition records, in this scenario we use the destination bin of the HU as decisive criterion for the route determination

The destination bin determination in inbound processes usually happens late in the process-oriented storage control. SAP S/4 HANA for Manufacturing Logistics however needs to determine the destination bin early in the process so that the route train process already knows at the beginning of the document flow where the HU will end up. This information of the final destination for putaway will be determined based on a PPF action /ILO/PDI_01_HU_UPDATE. It determines the destination bin and calls the logistical revaluation to determine the route based on the destination bin. Logistical revaluation then updates the route on inbound delivery item level and HU level.   

After the route has been determined the process for the route train does not differ from the already known loading and unloading process for production supply processes:

Figure 4: Warehouse task with route for inbound delivery

You load your HU and create a tour.

Figure 5: Load HU in RF onto your towing vehicle 

You start the unloading process by departing from the start point

Figure 6: Start unloading process

You unload your HUs at the destination bins and complete your tour.

Figure 7: Unload HU to final destination bin in storage type T040

With this you have loaded HUs from production and brought them back the warehouse for putaway.  More details can be foound on the official help page. 

Goods receipt from external vendors

A similar process exists for inbound deliveries from external vendors. SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics supports inbound deliveries with a TM scenario using Inbound Cargo registration and inbound deliveries without TM integration. Both processes share the same concept for the route determination: the determination procedure is assigned to the document type and suitable condition records are created.

Inbound deliveries from ICR usually have subHUs in topHUs. The system determines a route for each subHU in the topHU. In case not all determined routes for all subHUs are identical you must manually repack the subHUs which do not fit to the determined route of the remaining HUs. 

For the route train process from external vendors the inbound delivery must be created e.g. manually or via ASN inbound processing. The route determination for an ICR-related delivery starts with the update of the status ‚Äúready for warehouse processing‚Äù. This triggers as usual the route determination.

The system then creates warehouse tasks for staging and loading. The HUs are loaded onto a tour and are then brought to the PSA or destination bin using the already well-known route train applications in RF.  

One important detail needs to be considered for the demand time calculation: when a HU has a reference to a JIT call and the JIT call has a demand time, then this time is used as the planned arrival time of the tour in case you work with tacted tours. The tour determination then tries to find a suitable tour, which has a end time before the planned demand time at the PSA so that the goods arrive in time at the PSA.

Required configuration

In order to determine a route for inbound deliveries, you need to configure a route determination procedure for your document type of the relevant inbound deliveries.

The stop concept of SAP S/4HANA for manufacturing logistics has been enhanced with release 2023 FPS01. While we supported before this release only PSAs as stops we now also support usual storage bins as destinations. You need to maintain the bins as stops in the Manage Stops app and can then use them in your route for planning and in your condition records for the determination of the route.

entry.title: Re: Advanced integration of other warehouse requests like...
entry.content:
Hello Doreen, 

the PMR-based route trains solution already exists in SAP S/4 HANA for Manufacturing Logistics 2103 and before. You can find some details of the configuration here:  official help page for route determination for 2103 

It is always required for the route train solution that the warehouse request item has a determined route ID. 

In a nutshell: please assign the determination procedure 0ILR01 to your document type for PMR and maintain condition records with the condition type 0IR1. This should solve the route determination issue.

Best regards and sorry for this very late reply

Martin

entry.title: Re: Connection BAS to TRL instance (Abap trial), Cloud Tr...
entry.content:
Hello Alfredo,
 
please don't follow the tutorial https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-custom-ui-bas-connect-s4hc.html for connecting BAS with ABAP trial instance as it is intended specifically for S/4HANA Cloud systems.

To my knowledge the steps in the tutorial https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-deploy-fiori-elements-ui.html should still work for an ABAP trial instance. I tested this briefly with my own trial account and instance:

1. Followed https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-trial-onboarding.html for initial ABAP trial onboarding.
2. Then followed https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-deploy-fiori-elements-ui.html with some minor adjustments:
Step 4.5: I used the SSO Passcode option to ensure I was logged in with my trial account user.
Step 5.4: The destination for default_abap-trial is not created during initial onboarding. You need to create it manually by selecting Cloud Foundry ABAP environment on SAP BTP and then choosing ABAP environment default_abap-trial.

Then it is possible for me to select the system and service successfully.

 



 

From your screenshot, I see an ABAP environment instance named MyNewAbapserver. If there are issues, you could delete its corresponding destination and recreate the destination for default_abap-trial from BAS as described above.
Also, please ensure you are using the same user across your ABAP trial account, ABAP trial instance, and BAS.

Hope this helps!

Best regards,
Peter

entry.title: Re: Wrong Translation in SCT (EN --> KO)
entry.content:
Hi @chulhyuk_choi,

Thank you for your patience while I confirmed this internally.

You are absolutely right. We've verified that the translation of "Material" to "ÏûêÏû¨" (Raw Material) is an error in the ESG context and needs to be corrected by our development team. We appreciate you for pointing this out with such clarity.

As this is a system-level translation that users cannot change, the correct next step is to create a formal support incident. This will allow us to officially track the issue and assign it to the responsible teams for a fix.

Could you please create an incident via the SAP for Me portal? To ensure it gets routed correctly, please use the following component:

  • Component: SUS-SCT (SAP Sustainability Control Tower)

In the incident description, feel free to link back to this community discussion. This will provide the development team with all the necessary context.

Thank you once again for helping us improve our solution. Please let us know if you have any questions during the incident creation process.

Best regards,
Kau√™ Da Hora
